comments.commentBody: One would be delusional if one takes good acting for substance. Good actors can recall stuff and work long hours but they are actors after all.  How do you ignore who is sponsoring her? Perhaps you should consider Bernie Sanders. Before you say, if he has "endurance", look up his 8 hr filibuster to tax cut to the wealthy. Very quickly you will realize who is working for people and who is working for mega corporations.

Good funny column, great post!
This was a performance for the ages - elegant, erudite, passionate, informed, articulate.
Wow, with the type of questioning she could have blown her top dozens of times. For sure I would have.
Even the haters accept Rhodes scholar Bill Clinton is a serious intellect but I doubt if he could have given an equal performance as HRC.
Every Republican on the Committee was severely diminished and the Republican members repeatedly saying it was about 4 dead Americans was abject and despicable and transparently a tissue of lies.
Some of us have been wobbly in regard to voting for HRC - thank you Kevin McCarthy, Trey Gowdy and your supporters for obliterating comprehensively any doubts that we had on that decision.
Jeanne, I could not agree with you more.

As someone who is Hillary's age I have a lot of energy and plan to keep on keepin' on for a long time. I also thought I had stamina; but after watching Hillary make like the Energizer Bunny I was duly impressed. She was amazing. I watched the entire hearing, which reminded me of some of the men I encountered during my long corporate career -- the ones who sneer at and interrupt women they are trying to bully and intimidate. I broke for lunch when they did, and was dutifully back on the sofa when everyone reconvened. (But I did have to slip out to use the loo and couldn't understand how they weren't taking any more breaks.) When we slipped into the evening hours and I saw Hillary sipping water I yelled to my husband -- who was working and listening with one ear -- that they'd better let her go to the restroom! I was beginning to worry about her; to me the Republicans now resembled the most repulsive Dickensian characters. My husband asked if they had started waterboarding her yet. He's an Independent as well as a WWII buff; he said Rep. Jordan reminded him of Goebbels and that he was done with the Republicans.

When Hillary started coughing and Chairman Gowdy asked her if she wanted to take a "60 second-two minute break" I was so angry I burst into tears. Big of him. When he finally cried "uncle" at 9:00 p.m. I was a wreck. But Hillary looked as fresh as when she started at 10:00 a.m.

Of course she has my vote. And I'm definitely looking into yoga.

Nobody is saying the police should stop setting limits. Society needs the police and it needs limits. What people are saying is that the police need limits, too. One of those limits is that police shouldn't be able to shoot anyone who might possibly (but not definitely) be maybe holding a gun. Because that description ("might possibly be holding a gun") refers to literally every citizen in the country, all the time.

I used to be a high school teacher. I learned that the secret to making my students behave was not to be incredibly harsh or constantly give them suspensions. The secret was also not to be totally lax and ignore everything they did wrong. The secret was to constantly make students very aware of where the boundaries were, and to have the threat of consequences, but to make good on those consequences only when absolutely necessary.

Police can tell someone to behave themselves and police can tell someone to stop mouthing off without hauling that person to jail for a week. Is that really so hard for police to understand?

Some of these officers remind me of an insecure first-year high school teacher. They have to do a lot of shouting and yelling because they are scared and lack confidence. But the solution is for the police to get confidence and get better at their job, not for the public to excuse the screaming and yelling and abusing of suspects.

I'd like to posit an alternative theory.

Crime has dropped almost everywhere in the country over the past few decades -- violent crime, shootings, homicides, burglary, vehicle break-ins, et al. In many places, especially large cities, it's been shown that this drop in crime has not been linked with any rise in police tactics, and in fact, that the drop in crime has occurred *in spite of* increasingly aggressive police tactics e.g. stop and frisk.

Could it be, perhaps, that the population is finally getting fed up (thanks to cell phones, GoPros, etc) with the seemingly endless police shootings, unnecessary use of force, et al, and this is translating it a boiling-over of aggression and anger that is finding outlets in flash points of rising crime in hot spots around the country?

[[Mr. Comey said officers who normally would have stopped to question suspicious people are opting to stay in their patrol cars for fear of having their encounters become worldwide video sensations. That hesitancy has led to missed opportunities to apprehend suspects and has decreased the police presence on the streets of the country’s most violent cities, he said.]]

What makes them "suspicious"? What was the probable cause?

Saggy pants? Dreadlocks? Black skin? Brown skin?

Or were they loitering and eyeing passing cars? Were they doing hand to hand drug deals?

How did they know the decision to stay in their cars "led to missed opportunities to apprehend suspects"?

If they didn't talk to anyone, how do they know?

It is entirely inappropriate for the Director of the F.B.I. to make such a significant policy assertion, when he has no evidence to back it up.

Apart from the inappropriateness, it is absurd to attribute to a complex concept -- crime -- a simple solution. In addition, changes in "crime" rate, are even more complex.

And, once again, we find someone who should know better equating correlation with causation.

Except the police sometimes don't limit themselves to violating the civil rights of criminals. They don't always think twice about violating mine, and yours, too. In my town, a police officer felt he had the right to rape his ex-girlfriend, while he was on the job and in uniform. Fortunately, our local police force had the temerity to arrest him. Many forces do not. These incidents should give women like you and me pause to reflect. It's not always someone else's ox that gets gored.

"If, though, the thuggery spreads to other areas"

"Other areas" such as? Are only certain areas to be protected and to be served by the police?

"I am all for violating the civil rights of criminals"

How can it be the case that you know that only people who are criminals are having their civil rights violated, given that anyone and everyone is "presumed innocent, unless proved guilty in a court of law"?

Actually they're not supposed to violate the civil rights of anybody including criminals.  Their job is to bring them in to be tried in a court of law.  They are not the judge, jury and executioners they believe themselves to be.

This is incredibly obvious. Not politically correct, of course, but obvious.

As long as it is thugs killing other thugs, I don't much care if the crime rate is up. If, though, the thuggery spreads to other areas, then I am all for violating the civil rights of criminals so that the rest of us can stay safe.

Except for the absurd FDR part, there is no way to recommend this comment highly enough.

Bill, FDR and his cronies put together the New Deal in order to stave off a revolution that would have resulted in a lot more than a better welfare state.

I would suggest that this is a police strike like the one New York City experienced after officers Ramos and Liu were murdered last December.

Frequently when police officers feel they are not being adequately supported they simply stop doing their jobs. Their message is clear, If you don't like how we police your jurisdiction, see how you like it when we stop.

There has to be a line between supporting brave, honest peace officers, like Officers Ramos and Liu, and giving anyone with a badge a blank check to shoot people in the back or harass vulnerable citizens into committing suicide.

We all need to work together to define acceptable standards for the use of force which will protect both police and citizens, and our peace officers need to keep doing their jobs, honestly and fairly, while we do.

" One might assume that readers making such inferences wouldn't likewise want to be wrongly judged for something they said, a position they held, or even for the way they look."

...or being caught on video clearly unloading your clip into the back of a man running away from you at a distance where he clearly posed no threat. Wouldn't want anyone to infer anything from that.

And that's the thing...it seems to me that all these viral videos are the shockingly clear incidents where there's no ambiguity that the police reacted with wholly inappropriate and excessive force. And even then, unless it's as as blatant as the cop being caught basically murdering a man in cold blood, they are virtually always cleared of wrongdoing. It just costs a lot money in lawyers and makes them look bad, that's why the brass has "no tolerance for a viral video".

So unless your contention is that most of these videos that go viral are actually unfair judgments, which I don't think you can, then by logical inference the argument that the police can't do their job for fear of being caught in an act of police brutality is in fact an argument in favor of police brutality.

What Mr. Comey seems to be suggesting is that the falling respect for police authority is the result of those who criticize the police for using unwarranted deadly force against black men, rather than the unwarranted use of deadly force itself.  Small wonder he can't find any evidence to support his theory.

The Justice Department's investigation didn't confirm this series of events, but merely stated that there wasn't the evidence present to bring a case against Wilson. We still don't know what happened. And, as best I remember, Wilson did not confront Brown as a robbery suspect, but as a jaywalker. Is taking cigars now robbery? Doesn't one have to be armed to commit robbery?
"A black man matching the description of a robbery suspect" = a black man.
How about instead of looking for a  black man looking for a robbery suspect how about looking for a robbery suspect period.

I work in law enforcement. The New York Times has done Comey a huge disservice by presenting his comments this way. Police are not afraid of extra "scrutiny". I welcome body cameras, I love the Bill of Rights, and I understand the importance of a diverse police department. I welcome better deescalation training and safer tactics. These things protect me as much as they protect anyone else.

But being the next Darren Wilson is my number two fear about being in this job (getting seriously hurt or killed is number one). Darren Wilson did absolutely nothing wrong - he confronted a robbery suspect, got assaulted, and defended himself. The Department of Justice's own investigation confirmed this. And yet he was vilified by the media, his department sued, he was sued, his city was set on fire, he lost his job and lives in hiding for the rest of his life.

So the next cop who sees a black man matching the description of a robbery suspect walking down the street is quite right to ask himself: Is it really worth it to stop him?

I ask myself the same question, and I say "Yes, it is worth it". But I understand the perspective of those in my line of work who say that it is not.

Whether or not link exist between public scrutiny of police brutally cases and a rise in crime, at best it's a gross error in judgment for Mr.Comey to suggest such a link does exist.  Mr. Comey statements have a profound effect on how agency employees do there job.  At worse, Mr. Comey's intends to prejudice future and current police brutality investigations by creating a safe environment for a police bias to infect FBI investigations.  Mr. Comey statements undermine the credibility of FBI investigations and by extension the credibility of the criminal justice system.   Mr. Comey should resign.

Police officers and criminals perhaps have different mindsets toward the issue than the general public. I for one cannot imagine how it is facing danger as part of routine. Meanwhile, there is room for improvement in terms of confronting racial profiling, poor police training, bad community-police relations, family and community conditions giving rise to crime, and workplace dynamics (in all sorts of formal organizations) that force people to place self-preservation before doing the job properly. The hard part is how to make actual improvement and who will do it.

On the one hand, this article suggests that Comey agrees that "increased attention on the police has made officers less aggressive and emboldened criminals." Comey then supposedly insisted that police officers are doing their jobs. So either the police are doing their job (and the officers who are less aggressive now are simply not acting improperly now), or the police are not doing their job. Both can't be true, assuming some aggressiveness is part of the job which I would assume it would have to be.

Regardless, of all the assumptions are seemingly made without data. I wish police would police themselves, but it appears that their reaction nationwide has mostly been belligerent denial.

Jim Comey is a career law enforcement officer and prosecutor. Now he has revealed himself to be a quintessential politician too. He should know better than to lend the prestige of the FBI to comments that are not based on any real data. Comments that have the ability to shape public opinion and the opinions of legislators who are at this very moment debating the pros and cons of major criminal justice reforms. Might he have been influenced by the understandable outrage over a very recent police shooting in NYC? Good law enforcement, even aggressive law enforcement, is good for us all. Overly-aggressive police officers imperil every one of us. My bet is that when the data is finally out, any increases in violent crime, if there are actually any, will actually turn out to be a function of many factors, none of which have anything to do with "emboldened" criminals acting on "fertile" ground.

If the police don't have anything to hide than they have nothing to fear, right?
Just like the pro-NSA pabulum 'If you've nothing to hide than you shouldn't be concerned'.
Let's face the fact the police are out of control in many, if not most places in America today. In part because they are doing exactly what they are trained and instructed to do by the people above them, who are told by those above them and on and on. This is all about control of the masses. And mainly through fear. It's the militarization of our police departments. In some pockets it's somewhat of an undeclared civil war really. Been going on for some time now really, especially in the inner cities.

Most thinking Americans are a bit (or a lot) fearful of cops today, exactly where they want us to be.

FBI Director is not great student of human psychology.  Any increase in violent crime results, not from less aggressive police officers, but from more expressive citizen releasing anger suppressed by those officers.

Just curious, Peter.  There is plenty of evidence that officers do/have done wrong (shooting a fleeing non-violent man in the back) and even are involved in organized criminal activity (remember the Knapp Commission).  And it's not all about BLM. Are you saying that if an officer does something seriously wrong, that that officer should not be help responsible because it will discourage others from doing their duty?

I am a retired NYPD officer/detective who served in the 60s & 70s in some very tough area, i.e. Fort Apache and later was in the Intelligence Division, the Organized Crime Control Bureau, and a stint in Federal Narcotics.

The brain dead comments by many commenters has me wondering about the reality testing of many of these writers. For instance, if you lived within a one mile circle of the 41Pct. station, you only had a 60% chance of dying from natural causes. 115-120 homicides per annum and a crime rate equal to any six Mid-Western states combined and we doing our best to protect the people with no body armor every day of the week.

Most of these writers have no clue about what police work entails, but they sit around listening to left wing commentaters vilifying the police and think they somehow know what is going on.

Why not give all police a 90 day paid leave and see how that works out for you.
How about putting on a blue uniform and strapping on a gunbelt and "walk the walk" for a year and then tell us what you think then?

"Remember that the next time you get mugged."

What should we do, if the "next time" is the first time? What should we remember? You must live a far more dangerous life-style than most other people do, if the *next* time that you get mugged is a constant cause of worry for you.

It continues to surprise me that many otherwise erudite readers of the NYT buy into the BLM narrative when it comes to criticizing the police. A few viral videos of isolated incidents across the country have enabled fringe elements to dismantle what has been up to now a functional law enforcement system which is largely staffed with dedicated, well-intentioned individuals.

In the last 18 months, we as a society vilified the very people who ensure that we exist as a functional society. This has not just been an exercise in dialogue - in the past 12 months, four NYPD officers have been killed by individuals who I would argue have been inspired by the vilification of police or benefitted from the roll-back of our criminal justice system.

The result is that many police officers are demoralized and feel little incentive to go after elements that cause crime in the first place lest the become the victim of a cause celibre against them in the form of viral video. Comey is really just stating what's being said by police officers across the country under their breath.

Mark my words: we will ultimately suffer for this (mis)adventure into police demonization under the guise of 'accountability' and 'social justice.' The result will be a vicious cycle of continued upticks in crime combined with increasingly beleaguered police departments that will be asked to do the impossible - reduce crime with their hands tied.

Remember that the next time you get mugged.

The most flagrant recent disrespect to authority has come about from the Bundy ranch and Oath Keepers, and the massive biker shootout in Texas. Seems like there are plenty of worthy targets for aggressive policing. Maybe the permissive attitude towards the steady flow of guns from responsible manufacturers to the hands of those with criminal intent should be investigated aggressively.

Absurd. Sentiment worthy of being fired.

The idea that holding police to account --requiring them to honor their oaths--their badges, --and Our Constitution --has somehow caused folks who would otherwise not act violently to suddenly make the cold calculation to act out violently is beyond absurd.

In the military, honor and heroism includes reporting misconduct; yet in police departments the bad apples are coddled by the "code of silence" --rendering would-be "heroes" (the good police officers) mute and neutered. Why can't police officers --and their bosses --speak up and report bad conduct?

The problem is not scrutiny, it is misconduct and too too many people, apparently including Comey, simply do not get it.

And isn't it the flip side of this poorly reasoned and even more poorly phrased 'argument' that we get more crime when there's too much policing where it's not needed?

As in, when these armed thugs kill children broad daylight because 'they feared for their lives'?

As someone else said, they're paid to risk their lives, not ours. But what we've got is a set of undisciplined thugs who grow fat on the public teat while they kill us for their sport.

Less policing where it's needed obviously leads to more crime. So if we want it we got it. And if we want the police to behave properly let set the rules of engagement. Otherwise of course a cop doesn't want to to be held responsible for the unpredictable actions in a momentous dangerous situation with no set rules.
But we will impose our opinion of him afterwards.
And we will blame him for not being up to our hindsight standards.
Or we already know who is guilty in advance?

The message he is saying is that the police need to be empowered to use force illegally and unnecessary and they need to be able to get away with it.

It's a pretty clear message. I'm guessing he gets a lot of support from the police.

I'd love to see what the comments are on PoliceOne but they no longer show them to citizens after those racist cops got caught being racist on the beat and it turned out they made racist comments on PoliceOne.

I think that's the sort of policy he wants to expand to include the public sphere.

No. What Mr. Comey expects that adults will listen to what he is trying to convey. That message is that we have a real problem, for everyone. Police and the public. He is opening a topic that is not easy to talk about. It involves complex conditions. And Mr. Comey has more than gone out of his way to speak to the American public about the issues that face us.

Did you even hear his speech at Georgetown University?

You choose. Help, and be part of the solution. Don't, then be part of the problem.

What a shockingly irresponsible thing to say. He is free to hold any views - it is not a crime to be ignorant, uninformed, or just plain stupid. But given the position he holds, didn't he think about the message he would be sending by making such assertions that have no clear evidence? I guess I shouldn't be surprised - people who can believe such things without any evidence are precisely the kind of people who would show such stupendous lack of judgment.

How did Reagan's every-man-for-himself travesty for a social compact take hold among such a potentially exemplary population?

It was(is?) taught in business schools under the name "comparative advantage." The theory became a mantra in the seventies that enabled the capitalist push for global trade by suggesting that the whole world would be better off if every person, business, and country pursued their/it's comparative advantage in skills and resources because the resulting increased worldwide productivity would 'trickle down', even to the disenfranchised who couldn't participate.

U.S. global corporate elite have gotten rich chanting that mantra while the country's citizens got a lot of cheap junk which they then had to buy repeatedly to achieve the same utility. Similar frauds were perpetrated upon the U.S. population before global trade using a very similar 'trickle down' scam that promised jobs instead of lower prices. About the only thing certain we can expect from any wealthy elite/government complex driven brainstorm is that the U.S. citizen population will be the sucker in the room every time.

The CA theory sounded OK but our senators didn't force a fair distribution of global trade benefits so CA theory made the comparatively advantaged elite more advantaged and everyone else more desperate. Elite criminals loath and suspect their injured victims so shooting same in the interest of 'maintaining civility' seems appropriate. Propaganda follows.
If the police would spend less time assaulting innocent professional basketball players or retired professional tennis players, then they might have more time to do real policing!

Robert:

David B. Benson is a trusted commenter southeast Washington state 1 day ago
"From the data in the linked Pulp Fiction, part 2, the total CO2 from burning non-waste biomass is 1.4 times that of burning coal."

He said that it released 1.4 times more CO2, not that it was "1.4 times worse for the climate."

Nice try, Sparkies, though your failure to yawp about CO2 being harmless (if not positively nifty) in the usual manner did kinda give the trick away. Don't let the rabbit ear stick out of the sleeve, next time, okay?

David,
Your reasoning is wrong.
First, the bulk of the EU demand is not coming from plantations (or "tree farms" in your parlance).
Second, even if it were coming from such plantations, it would not be good at all. Even the amount that is coming from harvesting plantations is beind denied by the likes of Drax and their host governments. They try to pretend that it is all coming from residues or thinnings, but not the harvest of forests or plantations.

There is a grain of truth in your storyline plantations could suck up the C emitted, but it could only be attributed to the energy use if the plantation were established for that purpose and on land that would otherwise not produce anything. I.e. If the bioenergy use created that sink. But that is not the case. The EU calculations essentially assign to the EU energy sector all the future carbon services of the US land concerned, even if the US will also lay claim to the regrowth (as their own sink).

And again, it is practically irrelevant to the EU's approach as essentially zero biomass is coming from new production created for this purpose. They are essentially saying that by virtue of harvesting an existin forest (plantation) to be burt, you can lay claim to the future carbon services of this land for eternity.

The EU biomass burning accounting rules are close enough to correct considering atmospheric CO2 alone. Here is the simplified argument:

Burning a unit of coal generates a unit of atmospheric CO2 which remains in the atmosphere for a long time. See David Archer's "The Long Thaw". I will take that time to be 50,000 years, just to simplify.

Assuming a well-run tree farm, the corresponding figure for burning biomass is 1.2--1.4 units of atmospheric CO2. But the tree farm regrows, so the residence time for the CO2 is but, say, 50 years.

That is one thousand times smaller global warming potential. That is so small I, along with the EU, will ignore the discount of the future. So the EU has the rule about right.

There are other values to actual forests beyond mere tree farms. There are many reasons not to cut down the forests. But not the main reason given in this post, which does misleading atmospheric CO2 accounting.
